scenario.title: Client with a Forearm Fracture
scenario.background: A 45-year-old construction worker is admitted to the orthopedic unit after a crush injury to the right forearm. The client underwent a closed reduction and application of a long arm cast for a comminuted fracture of the radius and ulna 4 hours ago. The nurse is preparing to perform a scheduled assessment.

exhibits.title: Nurse's Note
exhibits.content:
Time: 1400
Client reports severe, deep, throbbing pain in the right forearm, rated as 9/10. States the pain is worse than it was an hour ago and was not relieved by IV morphine administered 30 minutes ago. Client describes the arm as feeling "extremely tight and swollen" under the cast. Also reports new onset of numbness and a "pins and needles" sensation in the right thumb and index finger.

OBJECTIVE:
Vital Signs: BP 148/92 mmHg, HR 112/min, RR 22/min, Temp 37.1°C (98.8°F), SpO2 99% on room air.
Right upper extremity: Fingers are pale and cool to the touch. Capillary refill is 4 seconds. Radial pulse is weak and difficult to palpate with a doppler. Obvious edema of the fingers is noted. Passive extension of the client's fingers elicits an extreme pain response.

stem: Based on the nurse's note, what is the priority action for the nurse to take?

options.text: Elevate the affected limb on two pillows.
Document the findings in the electronic health record.
Administer the next scheduled dose of IV morphine.
Notify the healthcare provider of the assessment findings.
Reassess the client's neurovascular status in 30 minutes.

correct.rationale: The client is exhibiting classic signs of acute compartment syndrome: pain out of proportion to the injury and unrelieved by opioids (9/10), paresthesia (numbness, pins and needles), pallor (pale fingers), coolness, delayed capillary refill (4 seconds), and pain with passive stretch. This is a surgical emergency that can lead to permanent limb damage if not treated promptly. The priority action is to notify the healthcare provider immediately to facilitate urgent intervention, such as bivalving the cast and preparing for a fasciotomy.

incorrect.rationale: Elevating the limb above the level of the heart is contraindicated in suspected compartment syndrome. While elevation typically reduces swelling, in this case, it can decrease arterial blood flow to the limb, further compromising perfusion and worsening the ischemia.

The client's pain is ischemic in nature, not solely nociceptive from the fracture. The fact that the pain was not relieved by a recent dose of a potent opioid is a hallmark sign of compartment syndrome. Administering more pain medication masks the progression of symptoms and delays definitive, limb-saving treatment.

While documentation is a critical part of the nursing process, it is not the priority in a time-sensitive, limb-threatening emergency. The nurse must act first to initiate intervention by notifying the provider. Documentation can occur after the immediate threat to the client is addressed.

The assessment findings are already critically abnormal and clearly indicate a serious complication. Delaying action to reassess in 30 minutes would allow the ischemic process to continue, increasing the risk of irreversible nerve damage and muscle necrosis. Immediate action is required.
